name: hydrogen cyanide production | hydrogen cyanide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/718/documentation

This data represents the production of 1 kg of hydrogen cyanide. Raw materials and emissions are modelled with literature values representing an aggregation of data from 3 production plants. Not included are the values reported for: recyclable wastes, amount of air / N2 / O2 consumed, unspecified metal emission to air and to water, mercaptan emission to air, unspecified CFC/HCFC emission to air, dioxin to water.  

From the reception of methane at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of 1 kg of hydrogen cyanide, 100% at the factory gate.  The dataset includes the input materials and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Historically, HCN gained notoriety for its use as Cyclon B at the Nazi death camps during World War II. It was produced at that time by DeGussa (Deutsche Gold- und Silberscheide-Anstalt). Sodium cyanide continued down HCN’s path to notoriety by being mining companies choice chemical used to extract gold from ore. However, poor practices led to massive environmental contamination in several countries over the past decades2.;The worldwide cyanide production capacity in 1994 was one million tonnes. DuPont is reported to be the dominant producer with close to 40% of production capacity. ;The U.S.produced about 1.4 billion pounds (645’000 tonnes) in 1998. ;;US production had the following uses: ;Share (%);Adiponitrile (for nylon):	41;Acetone cyanohydrin (for methyl methacrylate MMA):	32;Sodium cyanide:	14;methionine:	4;miscellaneous:	9;;Major manufacturers include Cyanco, DeGussa-Huls Corp., Dow Chemical Co. and DuPont.;In 1997-2000, European production of toluene was approximately 2.7 million tons. Major plants are operated in Germany, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain, the UK, the US, Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, among others. Major manufacturers include DeGussa, Dow and DuPont.;;HCN is produced mostly from the Andrussow and Blausäure-Methan-Ammoniak (BMA) processes, although some HCN is also obtained as a by-product from acrylonitrile production.;Andrussow process:;Filtered air, ammonia and natural gas are fed into a reactor and are heated to 2’200 °C in the presence of a catalyst. The reactor off-gas in cooled and sent through an ammonia absorption process to remove unreacted ammonia. Cold water is then added to capture the HCN. The HCN-water mixture is sent to a stripper, where pure HCN is gained. This step produces wastewater.;2 NH3  + 2 CH4 +   3 O2   2 HCN  + 6  H2O	(1);;Blausaure-Methan-Ammonia Process:;The BMA process involves the reaction of ammonia with methane without the presence of air. After removal of ammonia and recovery of HCN, the off-gases consist basically of hydrogen. The hydrogen can be used in other processes or burnt as a source of energy. ;2 NH3  + 2 CH4    2 HCN  + 6  H2	(2);;BMA accounts for 15 % of the total European production. ;;The production process for hydrogen cyanide was assessed with data based on the years 1992 – 1993 and accounts for about 63’000 tons of HCN produced at three sites in Europe. It cannot be ascertained which processes were used by the companies providing the data – the hydrogen emissions that are listed are no indicator of the actual processes, as hydrogen stemming from the BMA process may be captured and used in other processes and still cause emissions. ;References:;http://www.moles.org/ProjectUnderground/reports/goldpack/goldpack_i.html ;;;European Commission (2002) Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC) - Reference Document on Best Available Techniques in the Large Vol-ume Organic Chemical Industry. Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Sevilla;US-EPA (2000) Inorganic hydrogen cyanide Listing Background Document. United States Environmental Protection Agency (US-EPA), Washington D.C. (United States of America)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: literature values based on company survey

exchanges.description:
HCN is a highly volatile and highly toxic colorless liquid that produces poisonous vapors at room temperature (almond odor). Its molecular weight is 27.03 g/mol. HCN melts at -13.2 °C, and boils just above 25°C. This chemical is used primarily for the production of synthetic fibers, plastics and nitrites.
EcoSpold01Location=RER
